title: Role of Localized Interfacial Phonon at FeSe/SrTiO3 Interface
content: The discovery of superconductivity in single unit-cell FeSe grown on SrTiO3 substrate has attracted strong research interest for its dramatically enhanced superconductivity transition temperature [1]. Understanding the underlying mechanism can potentially guide us to utilize interfacial enhancement and achieve record-high superconductivity transition temperature. Itâ€™s believed that the phonon modes at the interface play an important role in the enhancement. Indeed, previous angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy studies showed that the strong electron-phonon coupling at interface is likely to be responsible for the formation of unique replica bands [2], while the recent high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy study suggests the Fuchs-Kliewer (F-K) phonons from the SrTiO3 may be the key of the electron-phonon coupling [3].
